Fig. 1 (a) NOx conversion over prepared catalysts (b) Toluene conversion over prepared catalysts (c) N2 selectivity (d) CO2 selectivity. Reaction condition: 100 ppm toluene, 500 ppm NOx, 500 ppm NH3, 10 % O2, N2 as balance gas, GHSV = 60,000 mL (g·h)−1. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and (b) the pore size distribution of different prepared catalysts. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of MCT catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a, b) SEM images of 1.5MCT. (c, d) Elemental mapping of 1.5MCT. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectrum of different MCT catalysts. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a)Mn 2p3/2, and (b) Cu 2p3/2, and (c) O 1 s XPS spectra of prepared catalysts. Distribution of (d) Mn, (e) Cu, (f) O species. Fig 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR curve of prepared catalysts. State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China At present, the emission of flue gas from the high-energy-consuming non-electric industries, represented by iron and steel, coking and cement, has become the main source of air pollution in China. Among these, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) are the main precursor for PM2.5 and ozone pollution. Herein, a series of MnCuTi ternary system catalysts with different Mn-Cu molar ratios were synthesized using the sol-gel method for the simultaneous removal of NOx and toluene. Combined with the catalytic performance and physicochemical properties, the results showed that the MnCuTi ternary catalysts possessed a large specific surface area and abundant mesopore structure. The synergistic effect between manganese and copper promoted the cyclic electron migration over the redox reactions, and improved the synergistic reaction performance of NOx reduction and toluene oxidation. Among different catalysts, 1.5MCT catalyst showed the best synergic activity, with 87 % NO conversion and 92 % toluene conversion at 240 °C. The interaction mechanism and the evolution of intermediate species in the collaborative reaction process were thoroughly revealed by in situ DRIFTS, it is discovered that NH3 and NOx inhibit the toluene oxidation due to the competitive adsorption and the nitrate deposition. However, when NH3 and NOx were introduced concurrently, they preferentially generated NH2NO, thereby diminishing their inhibitory effect. This study provided theoretical basis and technical support for multi-pollutant collaborative control in steel/coking industry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ternary catalyst NOx Toluene Simultaneous reaction mechanism In situ DRIFTS Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Coal has always occupied a dominant position in China, and its transformation and utilization process produce a variety of gaseous pollutants, including sulfur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which are believed to be the cause of haze and ozone pollution [1–3]. At present, the removal technology of NOx is mainly NH3 selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) [4,5], while the catalytic oxidation is the mainstream treatment of VOCs [6–8]. It is widely recognized that NH3-SCR catalysts generally have catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, and given that the temperature window for NOx reduction and toluene oxidation is closely aligned, hence, it is theoretically feasible to achieve synergistic removal of NOx and toluene [9–11]. Moreover, from the practical engineering, if the removal device of SCR and VOC can be coupled into a device, the occupation and investment of the device will be greatly slashed [12–14]. Therefore, to learn the simultaneous removal of NOx and VOCs holds substantial practical implications. From the point of catalyst classification, due to the high price of precious metal catalysts, transition metal oxide catalysts have attracted more and more attention in recent years [15,16]. Mn is one of the most popular transition metals in NH3-SCR and VOCs catalytic oxidation for its variable valence, strong oxidation and environmental friendliness [17–19]. However, on account of its strong oxidation, Mn often leads to the excessive oxidation of NH3 and the side reaction of non-selective catalytic reduction (NSCR), producing a large amount of N2O, which is a non-carbon dioxide greenhouse gas, having an adverse effect on the atmosphere. In order to compensate for this defect, Mn-based catalysts are often combined with other transition metal elements, such as Cu, Ce, Co, Fe, Ti, etc. [20–24]., building binary or ternary composite Mn-based catalysts. Furthermore, thanks to the strong synergistic effect between Cu and Mn, Cu can promote the electron transfer between CuO and MnOx, and construct the redox cycle, viewed as an ideal modified metal [25]. For example, Shen et al. reported that Cu-doped SmMn2O5 mullite catalysts exhibited a great performance of toluene removal via active Cu2+-O-Mn4+ sites [26]. Yan et al. used layered double hydroxides as precursors to prepare Cu1Mn0.5Ti0.5Ox catalysts for NH3-SCR, which showed high De-NOx efficiency and excellent SO2 and H2O resistance [27]. With retaining the advantages of Mn-based catalyst, ternary system catalysts can also broaden the temperature range of simultaneous reaction and improve the resistance of SO2 and H2O. Furthermore, the synergistic reaction mechanism and the influence of SCR atmosphere on toluene oxidation remain a topic of debate. Lu et al. [28]. claimed that the addition of SCR reactants consumed the intermediates of toluene oxidation on MnCe/HZSM-5 catalysts, thereby increasing toluene conversion and reducing CO2 selectivity. Liu et al. [29]. synthesized CeO2-TiO2 catalysts, and speculated that NO could react with carboxylate produced by oxidation of toluene, thus promoting toluene oxidation. By contrast, Pan et al. [30]. prepared Mn/CeO2 and Mn/TiO2 catalysts, and found that NH3-SCR reaction and toluene oxidation showed mutual inhibition due to the competitive adsorption and oxidation of active oxygen species. Jia et al. [31]. reported that NH3-SCR and toluene oxidation were mutually inhibitory on the MnOx nanorod catalysts, with the inhibition being more obvious when NH3 and NO were present at the same time. In summary, the mechanism of SCR atmosphere and toluene oxidation is still valuable to explore, especially their effects on the morphology and reaction path of the oxidation intermediates are urgent. During the synergistic removal, the electronic interaction between reaction components and the catalyst, as well as the mechanism of the synchronous removal should be elucidated, so a series of MnCuTi ternary catalysts with different Mn/Cu molar ratios were prepared and applied to the simultaneously removal of toluene and NOx in this work. Systematic experiments and characterizations were used to investigate the relationship between the physical and chemical properties of the catalysts and toluene/NOx removal performance. In addition, the mechanism of the synergistic removal was revealed, and the influence of SCR atmosphere on the oxidation of toluene was clarified through in situ DRIFTS, which is expected to guide the industrial applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this work, MnCuTi catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method. A certain amount of Mn(NO3)2 (50% wt in water) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were firstly dissolved in anhydrous ethanol, and then 8 ml of deionized water and 8 ml of glacial acetic acid were added, and the solution A was obtained by stirring it evenly at room temperature. Then a certain amount of butyl titanate was mixed with anhydrous ethanol and stirred evenly at room temperature to obtain solution B. With intense agitation, solution B was added to solution A drop by drop, and continued to stir at room temperature for 3 h, and then stood at room temperature for 2 h to form transparent sol, dried at 70 °C for 12 h, and then dried at 120 °C for 12 h. Eventually, the dried samples were put into a tube furnace and calcined at 450 °C under air atmosphere for 5 h, after which grounded and sieved to 40–60 mesh. The resulting catalysts were denoted as xMCT, where the molar ratio of Mn+Cu to Ti was fixed at 1:4. (x = n M n n M n + n C u = 1.25,1.5,1.75). What is more, MT and CT were prepared as comparison. 2.2 Catalyst performance evaluations The activity evaluation was conducted within a fixed bed quartz reactor, possessing an inner diameter of 6 mm. The concentration of all gases in the reaction system was monitored by DX-4000 infrared flow gas analyzer. More detailed information of performance evaluations was offered in Supplementary Material. 2.3 Characterization The physical and chemical properties of prepared catalyst were obtained through a series of experiments and characterizations. The detailed descriptions were listed in Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of simultaneous removal of NOx and toluene The simultaneous removal activity of toluene and NOx over the prepared catalysts at temperature ranging from 180 °C to 300 °C was exhibited in Fig. 1 . As illustrated in Fig. 1(a), the highest NOx conversion was observed with 1.5MCT between 180 °C and 240 °C, achieving a rate of 87 % at 240 °C. In contrast, MT and CT had lower NOx conversion compared to MCT catalysts. As for toluene degradation, toluene conversion for the synergistic removal of the five catalysts was depicted in Fig. 1(b). This figure referred that the toluene conversion on 1.5MCT was the most pronounced, reaching up to 90 % at 234 °C, followed by 1.25MCT and 1.75MCT. In fact, the T90 of prepared MCT catalysts was similar, while that of MT and CT was 30 °C higher than 1.5MCT. CO2 selectivity exhibited an ascending trend of 1.75MCT<1.5MCT<1.25MCT, because the intermediate species formed by toluene on 1.5MCT at 240 °C has not completely decomposed. In conclusion, the catalytic performance of MCT catalysts were better than that of MT and CT, and 1.5MCT catalyst showed the best simultaneous removal performance of toluene and NOx under the test condition. 3.2 Morphology and structure properties 3.2.1 N2 adsorption-desorption In heterogeneous catalysis, the specific surface area as well as channel structure of the catalyst were crucial, particularly in NH3-SCR and toluene oxidation, where surface adsorption was an indispensable stage. The results of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and average pore size of the prepared catalyst were illustrated in Fig. 2 . As can be observed in the figure, all samples presented typical Langmuir IV adsorption isotherm and H3 type hysteresis loop when P/P0=0.4–1.0, suggesting that all samples had typical mesoporous structures [32]. The sol-gel method was used in the preparation process, making the colloidal particles have electrostatic interaction, which hindered the growth of crystals and was also conducive to the formation of the intermediate pore structure of the catalysts. What can be figured out from Fig. 2(b) was that the pore size distribution of all samples was concentrated within the range of 3–8 nm, referring that the catalysts contained abundant mesoporous structure. The rich mesoporous structure in the catalyst can not only play a significant role in the adsorption of reactants and gas phase oxygen, but also expose more active sites on the catalyst surface to improve the simultaneous performance. The average pore diameters and pore volumes of these five catalysts are detailed in Table 1 . It is revealed that the average pore diameter of the catalysts ascended gradually with the increase of manganese proportion. The pore volumes of other samples were between 0.27 and 0.28 cm3/g, except for CT being 0.21 cm3/g. In terms of the specific surface area, 1.25MCT and 1.5MCT focused on 163–165 m2/g, while 1.75MCT and MT were reduced to 155–157 m2/g. The enhanced adsorption and activation of reactants on the catalyst surface can be attributed to its larger specific surface area, which elucidated why both 1.5MCT and 1.25MCT showed better simultaneous removal performance. 3.2.2 XRD To ascertain the microstructure details of MCT catalysts, XRD were conducted on 1.25MCT, 1.5MCT and 1.75MCT samples in Fig. 3 . The XRD pattern of MCT catalyst mainly showed anatase type TiO2 crystal phase (PDF#21–1272), and there was no obvious diffraction peak of manganese oxide or copper oxide in the spectrum, indicating that manganese and copper were highly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst and existed in amorphous form. It has shown that lower crystallinity enhances the adsorption of oxygen on the catalyst surface, thus promoting the activity of the synergistic reaction [33,34]. 3.2.3 SEM SEM was used to further understand the microstructure of MCT catalyst, as presented in Fig. 4 . It is denoted that 1.5MCT presented a granular structure, which was helpful for the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules. Besides, it is found that Mn and Cu were distributed on the surface of catalyst uniformly by elemental mapping, which was consistent with XRD results. 3.3 Raman analysis As demonstrated in Fig. 5 , the Raman signal at 600–650 cm−1 belonged to the symmetric stretching vibration of Mn-O in [MnO6] octahedral [35]. Astonishingly, compared with the other two MCT catalysts, the Mn-O peak position of 1.5MCT marked a 10 cm−1 shift in the direction of low wave number, which revealed the improvement of lattice oxygen reactivity. Moreover, the peak at 154cm−1 was attributed to anatase [36], and the peak of 1.5MCT here was significantly weaker than that of 1.25MCT and 1.75MCT, indicating that the synergistic effect among Mn, Cu and Ti was the strongest, which was one of the reasons for the best activity. 3.4 XPS To explain the valence state of the active center and the composition of surface oxygen, we conducted XPS analysis. This analysis further provided insights into the redox ability of the catalyst. The quantitative calculation of the surface relative proportion was detailed in Table 2 . As presented in Fig. 6 (a), the XPS spectra of Mn 2p3/2 was composed of three subpeaks at 640.5 eV,641.8 eV,643.0 eV, which corresponded to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ [37]. As depicted in Fig. 6(d), Mn3+ was the dominant manganese species in several MCT catalysts, and Mn4+/Mnn+ at 1.5MCT was the highest, being 31.9 %. According to the previous reports, Mn4+ not only had a significantly impact on the catalytic oxidation of VOCs, but also was the active site of NH3-SCR at low temperature. A higher percentage of Mn4+/Mnn+ was beneficial to the circulation of oxygen species on the catalyst surface. This was because a greater number of surface Mn4+ ions can fill the oxygen vacancies in the oxide material, facilitating the adsorption, activation, and migration of oxygen in the gas phase. As a result, this process promoted the catalytic oxidation of toluene [38,39]. Furthermore, during the NH3-SCR reaction, Mn4+ was believed to accelerate the conversion of NO to NO2 during low-temperature SCR, fulfilling its role in the SCR reaction, which can explain why the NO conversion and toluene conversion of 1.5MCT exceeded those of other prepared catalysts. In Fig. 6(b), the Cu 2p3/2 spectra was divided into two peaks at about 933.5 eV and 935.0 eV, which belonged to Cu+ and Cu2+ species on catalysts surface [40]. The binding energy position of MCT was higher than that of CT, demonstrating that Mn and Cu had a strong interaction, which dropped the electron cloud density around Cu atom. Obviously, Fig. 6(e) provided that the ratio of Cu2+/Cun+ at each MCT catalyst was much higher than CT, indicating that the Mn addition facilitated to the valence change of Cu+ to Cu2+. It had been proved that higher percentage of Cu2+ can induce the formation of oxygen vacancy and promote the oxidation of toluene [41]. Moreover, it could be explained that a possible redox reaction Mn4+ + Cu+ → Mn3+ + Cu2+ took place between Mn and Cu, which lead to a certain electronic transfer process. As depicted in Fig. 6(c), the XPS spectra of O 1 s was composed of two peaks at 529.6 eV and 531.2 eV, which corresponded to the lattice oxygen (Olat) and chemisorbed oxygen (Oad) [42]. The ratio of chemisorbed oxygen ratio on the three MCT catalysts was similar, about 21 %−26 %, and depicted a slight decrease with the rise of Mn proportion. Chemisorbed oxygen played an important role in both toluene oxidation and SCR process [43], and that of 1.25MCT and 1.5MCT catalysts were higher than others, corresponding to their excellent activity. 3.5 Redox capability and oxygen species mobility The redox property of catalysts is important to NH3-SCR, toluene oxidation, as well as the synergistic removal of NOx and toluene, therefore, H2-TPR was employed to characterize the redox property of the synthesized catalysts. Fig. 7 illustrated the H2-TPR curve for the catalysts under consideration, and the consumption amount of H2 was listed in Table 3 . The data clearly revealed two distinct low-temperature reduction peaks for CT, corresponding to the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu+ to Cu0. Also, there were two reduction peaks of MT at 364 °C and 504 °C, which were attributed to Mn4+ → Mn3+ and Mn3+ → Mn2+ respectively [44,45]. In the meantime, two reduction peaks also appeared in the curves of three MCT catalyst samples, in which the lower temperature peak corresponded to the reduction peak of Cu2+ → Cu+, and the other one attributed to the reduction peak of Mn4+ → Mn3+, because the synergistic interaction between Mn and Cu made the electrons migrate rapidly between Cu2+, O2−, and Mn3+, which agreed to the conclusion of XPS. According to Fig. 7, the reduction peaks of Cu2+ → Cu+ and Mn4+ → Mn3+ shifted to high temperature by the increase of Mn proportion, which proved a gradual weakening of the catalyst redox properties. Despite the fact that the Cu reduction peak temperature of CT was the lowest, the catalytic performance was unsatisfied, which revealed that the strong oxidation centers (Mn4+ and Mn3+) on the catalyst took a lead in the simultaneous removal, and only the single Cu site had a limited effect on the simultaneous removal. In terms of MCT catalysts, the reduction peak position of 1.5MCT was in the middle. When combined with its best results from simultaneous activity evaluation, it suggested that maintaining a balance between oxidation and reduction is crucial for simultaneously removing NOx and toluene. The mobility of oxygen species in the synthesized catalysts was examined using O2-TPD, and O2 consumption amount was listed in Table 3. Generally, the O2 desorption peak can be divided into three types, the physically and chemically adsorbed oxygen within the temperature range of 100–300 °C, the surface lattice oxygen at 300–550 °C, the bulk lattice oxygen above 550 °C [46]. As shown in Fig. 8 , a desorption peak can be observed in all catalysts near 250 °C, and the peak intensity and location of the prepared catalysts were very close, indicating that the proportion of physically and chemically adsorbed oxygen of the prepared catalysts was similar, which was in accordance with the result of XPS. Besides, although MT showed a strong desorption peak at 350 °C, the ability of simultaneous removal was poor, which proved that only a large amount of lattice oxygen could not complete the synergistic removal of NOx and toluene, and the electron cycle constructed by Cu and Mn was still of vital importance. 3.6 NH3-TPD analysis NH3-TPD experiments were executed to illustrate the surface acidity and acid content of catalysts in Fig. 9 . The desorption peak lower than 200 °C was ascribed to weak acid sites, while the peak ranging from 200 °C to 400 °C was associated with medium acid sites. The desorption peak at high temperature above 400 °C was attributed to strong acid sites (mainly Lewis acid) [47]. The Lewis acid sites were the primary adsorption sites for toluene and NH3 in the simultaneous removal reaction [48]. As listed in Table 4 , the total acid content of 1.5MCT was the highest among MCT catalysts, and it had the largest strong Lewis acid sites, which agreed with its synergistic performance. 3.7 In situ drifts analysis 3.7.1 Reaction mechanism of toluene oxidation To figure out the reaction mechanism, in situ DRIFTS were conducted. In situ DRIFTS experiments for toluene oxidation were carried out at 150 °C and 250 °C respectively on 1.5MCT, and the results were exhibited in Fig. 10 . At 150 °C, the bands at 1493 cm−1 and 1592 cm−1 belonged to skeleton stretching vibration of aromatic ring, confirming that toluene was adsorbed on the catalyst [49,50]. The band at 1646 cm−1 was caused by vibration of C = O bond in benzaldehyde, and two pronounced bands were detected at 1407 cm−1 and 1536 cm−1, corresponding to benzoate species [51]. What is more, vibrational bands of maleate and maleic anhydride were observed at 1446 cm−1 and 1307 cm−1, respectively [34]. Through these results, in the case of toluene oxidation alone, the aromatic ring can be opened at 150 °C, and the band representing benzoate was the most prominent. At 250 °C, the band intensity of intermediate species decreased greatly, and the characteristic bands attributed to carbonate and small molecule acids appeared at 1357 cm−1 and 1382 cm−1, which denoted that toluene can be oxidized more deeply at this temperature [34]. It is inferred that toluene initially adsorbed onto the surface of 1.5MCT and converted into benzaldehyde, benzoate, maleate, which can be further converted into maleic anhydride, carbonate, small molecule acids and other deep oxidation products at high temperature. 3.7.2 Effect of scr atmosphere on toluene oxidation To delve deeper into the influence of SCR atmosphere on the oxidation of toluene, NH3/NO separately added to the oxidation system of toluene was designed to find out its influence mechanism on toluene oxidation. First of all, NH3 was introduced into the toluene oxidation system, the in situ DRIFTS result was displayed in Fig. 11 . At 150 °C, only the characteristic band of coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid site at 1189 cm−1 and the weak band representing the skeletal C = C stretching vibration of the aromatic ring at 1600 cm−1 appeared, and no other intermediates was detected. In comparison with the result of Fig. 10, NH3 had a strong competitive adsorption on toluene obviously [46]. At 250 °C, the band of coordinated NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites was greatly reduced, and maleate, the ring-opening product of toluene was also detected. However, the peak of carbonate and small molecular acid, the deep oxidation product of toluene did not appear, indicating that NH3 still inhibited the oxidation of toluene. After NO was added to the toluene oxidation system, the bands attributed to unstable nitro species (1214 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1248 cm−1) were found at 150 °C meanwhile, the characteristic bands of toluene adsorption and benzoate were also detected [45,52]. At 250 °C, the band of bidentate nitrate became stronger, and there was still no band of toluene ring-opening species, illustrating that nitrate deposition covered the active site on the catalyst, which made it difficult to further ring-opening after the conversion of toluene to benzoate, thus inhibiting the oxidation of toluene. When NH3-SCR and toluene oxidation occurred simultaneously, as shown in Fig. 11(e)(f), no intermediate species of nitrate and toluene conversion were found at 150 °C, whereas the band of NH2NO was detected at 1481 cm−1, which revealed that NO reacted preferentially with NH3 to form NH2NO instead of nitrate species [53]. At 250 °C, the bands of NH2NO and adsorbed NH3 disappeared, with intermediate species of toluene oxidation such as benzoate and maleate being found, which demonstrated that NH3 reacted with NO through the selective catalytic reduction process, and NO was rapidly converted into N2 and H2O, thus weakening the inhibition of NO on the oxidation of toluene. Based on the results of in situ DRIFTS experiment mentioned above, the mechanism for simultaneous removal of NOx and toluene over MCT catalyst was proposed in Scheme 1 . In the simultaneous process, toluene and NH3 competed to adsorb on the Lewis acid sites on the catalyst, and toluene was gradually oxidized to benzaldehyde, benzoate, maleate, maleic anhydride, carbonate or small molecular acid, and CO2+H2O. The redox cycle of Mn4+ + Cu+ → Mn3+ + Cu2+ promoted the electron transfer between Mnn+ and Cun+. At the same time, NH3 combined with NO to form NH2NO, and further to form N2 and H2O. 4 Conclusion To sum up, MCT catalysts incorporating varying ratios of manganese and copper were synthesized using the sol-gel method. Notably, the 1.5MCT exhibited superior synergistic performance, with NO conversion reaching to 87 % and toluene conversion achieving 92 % at 240 °C. Through a range of characterization, the prepared MCT ternary catalysts depicted the advantages of large specific surface area, abundant mesoporous structure and brilliant electron circulation between manganese and copper. The oxidation pathway of toluene on MCT catalyst was examined using in situ DRIFTS, and the impact of SCR atmosphere on the toluene oxidation was revealed. The competitive adsorption of NH3 and toluene inhibited the oxidation of toluene, and nitrate deposition of NO oxidation intermediates on the catalyst surface inhibited the ring-opening of toluene. When NH3 and NO were concurrently introduced, the inhibition was diminished in that NO reacted preferentially with NH3 to form NH2NO rather than nitrate species. coredata.dc:description: At present, the emission of flue gas from the high-energy-consuming non-electric industries, represented by iron and steel, coking and cement, has become the main source of air pollution in China. Among these, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and nitrogen oxides (NOx) are the main precursor for PM2.5 and ozone pollution. Herein, a series of MnCuTi ternary system catalysts with different Mn-Cu molar ratios were synthesized using the sol-gel method for the simultaneous removal of NOx and toluene. Combined with the catalytic performance and physicochemical properties, the results showed that the MnCuTi ternary catalysts possessed a large specific surface area and abundant mesopore structure. The synergistic effect between manganese and copper promoted the cyclic electron migration over the redox reactions, and improved the synergistic reaction performance of NOx reduction and toluene oxidation. Among different catalysts, 1.5MCT catalyst showed the best synergic activity, with 87 % NO conversion and 92 % toluene conversion at 240 °C. The interaction mechanism and the evolution of intermediate species in the collaborative reaction process were thoroughly revealed by in situ DRIFTS, it is discovered that NH3 and NOx inhibit the toluene oxidation due to the competitive adsorption and the nitrate deposition. However, when NH3 and NOx were introduced concurrently, they preferentially generated NH2NO, thereby diminishing their inhibitory effect. This study provided theoretical basis and technical support for multi-pollutant collaborative control in steel/coking industry.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the mechanism of simultaneous removal of NOx and toluene by MnCuTi ternary catalyst
